Line: I feele her [my soul] free, How she doth rowze, and like a Faulcon stretch Her siluer wings, as threatening death, with death; At whom I ioyfully will cast her off:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: this bodie but a sinck of folly,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: [body] The ground-work, and rais'd frame of woe and frailtie

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: [body] The bond, and bundle of corruption;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: [body] A quick corse, onely sensible of griefe,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: [body] A walking sepulcher

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: [body] household thiefe:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: [body] A glasse of ayre, broken with lesse then breath,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: [body] A slaue bound face to face, to death, til death:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: life is but a darke and stormy night, Of sencelesse dreames, terrors, and broken sleepes;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: [life] A Tyranie, deuising paines to plague And make man long in dying, racks his death;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: death is nothing,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: I bring a long Globe, and a little earth, Am seated like earth betwixt both the heauens: That if I rise; to heauen I rise; if fall I likewise fall to heauen;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: I will not die Like to a Clergie man; but like the Captaine,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: [I will die] but like the Captaine, That prayd on horse-back and with sword in hand, Threatend the Sunne, commanding it to stand;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: These [hangman's noose] are but ropes of sand.

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: all the world forsakes me! wretched world, Consisting most of parts, that flie each other:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: A firmnesse, breeding all inconstancy,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: A bond of all disiunction;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: like a man Long buried, is a man that long hath liu'd;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Why should I keepe my soule in this dark light? Whose black beames lighted me to loose my selfe.

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: How often will yee make me suffer death?

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: die most cruellie to heare so often My crimes and bitter condemnation vrdg'd:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: The common deposition, and her whoore To all whorish periuries and treacheries.

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: he cal'd vp the diuill in my spirits, And made him to vsurpe my faculties:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Take this true euidence, betwixt heauen and you, And quit me in your hearts.

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: all your forces should not Stire me one foote;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: wild horses should haue drawne My body peece-meale, ere you all had brought me.

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: They tread no ground, but ride in ayre on stormes, That follow State,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: hunt their empty formes; Who see not that the Valleys of the world, Make euen right with the Mountains, that they grow Greene, and lye warmer; and euer peacefull are, When Clowdes spit fire as Hilles, and burne them bare?

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Not Valleys part, but we should imitate Streames, That run below the Valleys, and do yeeld To euery Mole-hill;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: euery Banke imbrace That checks their Currants; and when Torrents come, That swell and raise them past their naturall height,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: How madd they are, and trubl'd? like low straines With Torrents crownd, are men with Diademes;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: There should go showtes to vp-shots; not a breath Of any mercy, yet?

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Death, slaue [to the executioner], downe,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: I do not ioy in sight of such a Pageant As presents death;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: you are blinde to this worlds sight, Looke vpward to a world of endles light;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: High Heauen curse these exemplarie proceedings, When Iustice failes, they sacrifize our example;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Out vgly Image of my cruell Iustice;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Let tame Nobilitie, and nummed fooles That apprehend not what they vndergo, Be such exemplarie, and formall sheepe;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Thinke you to set rude windes vpon the Sea, Yet keepe it calme?

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: or cast me in a sleepe, With shaking of my chaines about myne eares?

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: you haue seene me free, From any care, of many thousand deathes!

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: view, this wounded bosome, how much bound Should that man make me, that would shoote it through;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: If thou wert cleere, the Continent of France, Would shrinke beneath the burthen of thy death,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: cleere your Iustice, here is no ground shrinks, If he were cleere it would:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: If he with all his foulenesse, Stood here in one Skale, and the Kings chiefe Mynion, Stood in another, here: Put here a pardon, Here lay a royall gift, this, this, in merit, Should hoyse the other Mynion into ayre:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: my desert might haue out-weighed my forfeyt:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: But danger, hauntes desert, when he is Greatest;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: His [danger's] hearty ills, are prou'd out of his glaunces,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Kings suspicions, needes no Ballances;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: keepe their faiths that bind them to the King,

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: proue no stomakers of my misfortunes;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Nor come to Court, till time hath eaten out, The blots, and skarres of my opprobrious death;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: farewell for euer: neuer more Shall any hope of my reuiuall see mee; Such is the endlesse exile of dead men.

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: All these [seasons], and all fruites in them yearely fade, And euery yeare returne: but cursed man, Shall neuer more renew his vanisht face;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: knees bent too late, Stick you in earth like statues:

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: see in me How you are powr'd downe from your cleerest heauens;

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Fall lower yet: mixt with th' vnmoued center, That your owne shadowes may no longer mocke yee.

Play: The Tragedy of Charles, Duke of Byron
Line: Flie, flie commanding soule, And on thy wings for this thy bodies breath, Beare the eternall victory of death.
